content: The PhD in Software Engineering at the University of Arizona is offered through the Systems and Industrial Engineering (SIE) department. It is designed for individuals wishing to pursue advanced research and scholarly work in software engineering and related areas. The program is housed in the College of Engineering on the Tucson main campus, with graduate advising available via the SFWE Graduate Program Coordinator.

content: PhD applicants in Software Engineering must hold a BS degree from a regionally accredited U.S. university or an equivalent international institution recognized by the University of Arizona. A minimum 3.0 cumulative GPA is required either overall or in the last 60 units of the undergraduate degree. Applicants should demonstrate proficiency in at least one programming language or have 1–2 years of software-development industry experience. A master’s degree is not required, but admitted PhD students may earn an MS in SFWE en route to the PhD. Application materials typically include transcripts, a statement of purpose, three letters of recommendation, and a resume or CV. Students from non-SFWE backgrounds may be assigned undergraduate deficiency courses.

content: The SFWE PhD degree requires a minimum of 68 graduate units, including 48 units of non-dissertation coursework, 12 units in a doctoral minor, 18 units of dissertation research, and 2 units of graduate colloquium. The Plan of Study serves as a contract with the university specifying which courses must be completed before the PhD can be awarded. Students must maintain at least a 3.0 GPA, earn a minimum of C in each course, and ensure that any transfer credits are A or B equivalents. In addition to coursework, students are expected to actively participate in research under the mentorship of a faculty advisor.

content: PhD students in Software Engineering may transfer up to 30 units of relevant graduate coursework from a prior master’s or other graduate program with approval from their faculty advisor. Only coursework (not thesis or research credits) can be applied, and all transferred courses must have been completed with grades of A or B or the equivalent at the original institution.

content: PhD students in Software Engineering must complete 15 units of SFWE core coursework. This includes 6 units from two required courses—SFWE 513 Software Engineering Research Methods (3 units) and SFWE 507 Foundations of Software Engineering (3 units)—plus 9 additional units drawn from SFWE 502, 503, 504, 505, or 506.

PhD students must enroll in 2 units of SFWE 695A Graduate Seminar/Colloquium, graded on a pass/fail basis. While enrolled, students are required to attend department seminars and, before completing the requirement, deliver a research presentation to the class. After completing the 2 units, students are strongly encouraged to continue attending seminars relevant to their research.

content: PhD students may count up to 3 units of SFWE 699 Independent Study toward their degree, provided the study covers a topic not offered through regular courses and the detailed plan is approved by the Graduate Studies Committee. SFWE 900 research credits cannot be counted toward the PhD degree requirements.

content: All SFWE PhD students must complete 12 units in a doctoral minor outside of SFWE. A minor advisor from the minor department is required and typically serves on the student’s comprehensive exam committee. Common minor fields include Systems & Industrial Engineering, Computer Science, Information Science, Statistics, Biomedical Engineering, Computer Engineering, Mechanical Engineering, and other engineering programs. Students may also pursue a split minor, completing 6 units in each of two minor programs, or a multidisciplinary minor, depending on program policies.

content: Doctoral students from other departments may choose to minor in Software Engineering by completing 12 SFWE units. The minor requires 6 units from SFWE core-area courses (such as SFWE 507, 502, 503, 504, 505, or 506) and 6 units of approved SFWE electives (including options like SFWE 501, 508–513). For split minors, students typically complete 6 units from SFWE core courses and 6 units from another program. Students must identify a SFWE faculty member to serve as their minor advisor.

content: The PhD Qualifying Exam (QE) in Software Engineering evaluates a student’s prerequisite knowledge before they begin intensive research. Students must take the QE by the end of their third semester. A Qualifying Exam Committee of 3–5 College of Engineering faculty, chaired by the student’s advisor, designs an exam based on the student’s graduate coursework and plan of study. The exam, typically a closed oral and/or written session of 45 minutes up to 3 hours, is approved one month in advance by the SFWE Graduate Studies director. The committee votes pass/fail by secret ballot; any majority of fail votes (including abstentions) results in failure. Students who fail may retake the QE once in the following semester, with at least one member from the original committee. Failing the second attempt results in removal from the SFWE PhD program.

content: The Doctoral Comprehensive Exam determines whether a SFWE PhD student has sufficient background to undertake their planned dissertation research. It includes written and oral components covering both major and minor fields. For the written portion, committee members pose questions based on the student’s dissertation proposal and specialization; students usually have several weeks to respond, and each member rates responses as pass or fail, potentially requesting revisions once. After successful written work, the oral exam typically includes a presentation on the proposed research and is evaluated on literature review, research depth/originality, and communication, each scored from 1 to 5. Passing requires scores of 3 or higher in all criteria from all committee members. The exam is usually taken at least one semester to a year before the final defense, and at least 9 months is recommended. Students may be allowed one retake of the oral comprehensive exam within four months, at the committee’s discretion. The committee generally has at least four members, including major and minor advisors and a minor representative.

content: The final examination for the SFWE PhD consists of the written dissertation and the public oral defense. The dissertation must clearly state the significance of the work, thoroughly review relevant literature, describe methods, present major findings, and discuss limitations, impact, and future research directions. Students must follow Graduate College formatting guidelines and share the dissertation with all committee members at least two weeks before the defense. The defense includes a public presentation and discussion of the research followed by a closed session with the committee. The committee evaluates the candidate’s ability to critically engage with the literature, formulate and solve original problems using SFWE methods, and clearly communicate research contributions. The defense must be publicly announced at least two weeks in advance via the GradPath Announcement of Oral Examination form. At least three qualified faculty members must serve on the dissertation committee, and all are expected to attend the entire defense.

content: SFWE PhD students may be supported through Graduate Teaching Assistantships (GTA), Graduate Research Assistantships (GRA), tuition scholarships, and competitive fellowships. GTA positions are limited, competitively awarded, and typically capped at six semesters for PhD students; online students are generally not eligible. GRA positions depend on faculty research grants and are arranged directly with faculty members. Tuition scholarships provide partial tuition waivers for students enrolled in at least nine graduate units and in good academic standing. The College of Engineering and Graduate College also offer fellowships, including the University Fellows Program, for highly qualified PhD students. Students funded by the SIE department must enroll in at least nine graduate units each semester to maintain their appointment.
